article.title: A giant with feet of clay: on the validity of the data that feed machine learning in medicine

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 illustrates the concept of representing reality in modeling. What does the limited size of the "Experience" box within the larger "Field of Experience" signify?
choices: Our ability to model reality is only limited by our available computing power.
We can only model a small portion of the complexities present in reality.
The "Field of Modeling" is constantly expanding as we gather more data.
Time is an irrelevant factor when considering the representation of reality.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows various biases affecting medical data. Which type of bias specifically relates to the way information is documented in medical records by healthcare professionals?
choices: Response Bias
Observer Bias
Sampling Bias
Nonresponse Bias

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure illustrates the difference between validity and reliability. In scenario C, how is the validity of the data assessed?
choices: By comparing the variance of data points between scenarios B and C.
By comparing the data points to an established reference truth.
By assessing the level of agreement between different raters.
By analyzing the distribution pattern of the data points.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4 showcases the concepts of homomodality and symmodality.  Which of the following statements best describes the difference between the two?
choices: Homomodality involves one label for different appearances, while symmodality uses different labels for the same phenomenon.
Homomodality describes different labels for the same appearance, while symmodality uses one label for different phenomena.
Homomodality and symmodality are essentially the same concept.
Homomodality pertains to visual perception, while symmodality relates to linguistic interpretation.

multiple_choice_question.text: Table 1 shows an example dataset from a medical context. What kind of uncertainty is being represented by the terms "confident," "highly confident," and "sure" associated with the "Bicuspid aortic valve" attribute?
choices: Aleatoric Uncertainty
Epistemic Uncertainty
Ontological Uncertainty
Sampling Bias

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 5 depicts a "linguistic variable" represented by fuzzy sets. What is the advantage of using fuzzy sets over crisp sets in representing a variable like "fever"?
choices: Fuzzy sets allow for more accurate measurement of temperature.
Fuzzy sets provide a more intuitive and nuanced representation of imprecise concepts.
Fuzzy sets are computationally less expensive than crisp sets.
Fuzzy sets eliminate the need for expert opinion in data analysis.
